document_title: Effects of spaceflight and ground recovery on mesenteric artery and vein constrictor properties in mice
summary_full: This study investigated the impact of spaceflight on the vasoconstrictor properties of mesenteric arteries and veins in mice, aiming to understand the mechanisms behind orthostatic hypotension observed in astronauts. Mice flown on space shuttle missions were compared to ground-based controls. The research found that spaceflight significantly reduced the magnitude and speed of vasoconstriction in mesenteric arteries in response to norepinephrine, potassium chloride, and caffeine. This impairment was linked to decreased levels of ryanodine receptor-3 mRNA, suggesting a compromised ryanodine receptor-mediated intracellular calcium release mechanism. Mesenteric veins also showed diminished constriction to norepinephrine after spaceflight. These vascular changes were observed immediately after flight and persisted for one day post-landing, but normalized by five days. The findings suggest that these spaceflight-induced vascular alterations could impair the ability to maintain arterial pressure during orthostatic stress upon return to Earth.
key_findings: Spaceflight significantly reduced vasoconstrictor responses in mouse mesenteric arteries to norepinephrine, KCl, and caffeine.
Spaceflight led to decreased ryanodine receptor-3 mRNA levels in mesenteric arteries, indicating impaired intracellular calcium release.
Mesenteric veins also exhibited diminished vasoconstriction to norepinephrine after spaceflight.
The impaired arterial vasoconstriction persisted for one day post-flight but recovered within five days.
Spaceflight did not alter active or passive myogenic responses of mesenteric arteries to pressure changes.
No gross structural changes in mesenteric artery wall thickness or maximal luminal diameter were observed after spaceflight.
future_research_fields: Investigating the specific circulating factors responsible for microgravity-induced smooth muscle dysfunction.

Determining the precise role of ryanodine receptor subtypes in spaceflight-induced vascular changes.
Developing countermeasures to mitigate vascular deconditioning during spaceflight.
Examining the effects of spaceflight on other vascular beds and their contribution to orthostatic intolerance.

conclusions: Spaceflight diminishes the vasoconstrictor responsiveness of mesenteric arteries and veins in mice, primarily through an impairment of the ryanodine receptor-mediated intracellular calcium release mechanism. These vascular changes, which occur without gross structural alterations, persist for at least one day post-flight but normalize within five days. These findings suggest that spaceflight-induced vascular dysfunction contributes to orthostatic hypotension and compromises the ability to maintain arterial pressure and mobilize blood volume during orthostatic and exercise stress upon return to Earth.
impact_statement: This study reveals that spaceflight impairs the ability of blood vessels to constrict, potentially explaining why astronauts experience dizziness and fainting upon returning to Earth, and highlighting the need for countermeasures to maintain cardiovascular health in space.
